intro: Wikstroemia sellingii, commonly known as the Hawaiian sandalwood, is a flowering plant native to the Hawaiian Islands. It belongs to the family Thymelaeaceae and is characterized by its small, fragrant white flowers that bloom in clusters. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, with lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to the humid, tropical climate of its native habitat. Due to its ecological and cultural significance, it is also considered a rare and endangered species.
